notesStmt.note: The canceled notes on the recto may have been composed between late December 1861 and December 1864. According to Whitman, the "Hospital" notes at the bottom of the page were composed while Union soldier Lewis Francis was in a Washington hospital. By Francis's testimony, he was in a Washington hospital for at least a week after December 21, 1861 but before April 16, 1862 ("Testimony of Lewis Francis," The Reports of the Committees of the Senate of the United States of the Second Session of the Thirty-Seventh Congress [1861–'62], 36). Francis was wounded in the first Battle of Bull Run on July 21, 1861 and returned home to Brooklyn in the spring of 1862. The draft letter on the verso is likely related to Whitman's editorial about the general exchange of prisoners, versions of which were published in the New York Times and the Brooklyn Daily Eagle on December 27, 1864.

div2.ab: Christmas night—the men had a theatrical performance Rob. Roy—2d floor "front seats reserved for the cripples"—where they were all in one building, the men had the run of the whole building—300 present at the performance of Rob. Roy,

Ideas of prison life—the idea of a sad, degraded, or altogether unhappy life is all wrong—the men were generally in good spirits—nobody shirked his duties—all behaved manly and as to union sentiment it was stronger than ever—the life was quite happy, and all the men returned healthy and fat,—Wounded and dying—occu asthere would be some sick, and of course deaths would occur every day

Hospital—Lewis Francis, Co. G. 14th (taken at Manassas Bull Run had 14 bayonet wounds in him) fought savage—(released 4 weeks since and is now in hospital in Washington—will get well) perhaps 200 in the 3 hospitals—unionVirginia prisoners—these are the most unhappy spirited of all—one man actually died from lice
